title: Shortest Path in Binary Matrix
content:
Given an n x n binary matrix grid, return the length of the shortest clear path in the matrix. If there is no clear path, return -1.

A clear path in a binary matrix is a path from the top-left cell (i.e., (0, 0)) to the bottom-right cell (i.e., (n - 1, n - 1)) such that:

  • All the visited cells of the path are 0.
  • All the adjacent cells of the path are 8-directionally connected (i.e., they are different and they share an edge or a corner).

The length of a clear path is the number of visited cells of this path.

 

Example 1:

Input: grid = [[0,1],[1,0]]
Output: 2

Example 2:

Input: grid = [[0,0,0],[1,1,0],[1,1,0]]
Output: 4

Example 3:

Input: grid = [[1,0,0],[1,1,0],[1,1,0]]
Output: -1

 

Constraints:

  • n == grid.length
  • n == grid[i].length
  • 1 <= n <= 100
  • grid[i][j] is 0 or 1

discussion_posts.name: icespeech
discussion_posts.content:
In the problem description, it gives two constraints for the definition of a **clear path**.
And constraint two says:

* **All the adjacent cells of the path** are 8-directionally connected (i.e., **they are different** and they share an edge or a corner).

What does **they are different** mean? Firstly I thought it means they are all 1s, because that's different from the 0s in the path. But in example 2, all the adjacent cells of the path are [[0,2],[1,0],[1,1],[2,1]], and they are not all 1s because cell [0,2] contains a zero. (As the pic shows.)
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/c89b9e6a-8591-4210-8964-717d5d209d0c_1651877883.2621098.png)

So maybe by **they are different** it means the adjacent cells are not included in the path? But should not that be self-evident?

Can anyone please give a clearer definition of it? Many thanks.
